Authors: Klodnick, Vanessa V.; Sabella, Kathryn; Brenner, Christopher J.; Krzos, Izabela M.; Ellison, Marsha L.; Kaiser, Susan M.; Davis, Maryann; Fagan, Marc A.
Article Title: Perspectives of Young Emerging Adults With Serious Mental Health Conditions on Vocational Peer Mentors
Abstract: For early emerging adults with serious mental health conditions, vocational services with peer mentors are a promising adaptation of adult system evidence-based practices. Peer mentors were added to the Individual Placement and Support model of supported employment for 17- to 20-year-olds receiving residential and psychiatric care. To explore the feasibility of vocational peer mentors, open-ended satisfaction surveys and the Working Alliance Inventory were administered to mentees at 12 months. Thematic analysis of surveys reveals the importance of peer mentor authenticity, flexibility, and being a graduate of the mental health program where vocational services were based. Valued relational processes include the act of talking in the community, feeling understood, and forming a bond with peer mentors. Mentees with positive peer mentoring experiences reported stronger working alliances. This study sheds light onto near-age mentoring relational processes for this population, which can inform future research of mentoring processes and intervention design.

llama-3.2-3b-instruct.reason: The study design lacks a control group.

qwen2.5-7b-instruct-1m.reason: The study lacks rigorous evaluation as it does not include a control group. It focuses on the perspectives and experiences of mentees rather than evaluating employment outcomes.

phi-3-mini-4k-instruct.reason: The study focuses on vocational peer mentors for young adults with serious mental health conditions, which does not directly address employment interventions for people with mental health disorders as specified in the inclusion criteria.

mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501.reason: The study does not include a control group and lacks a rigorous evaluation.
